awd_abstract_narration:
NSF CAREER awards support early career faculty who integrate their research and educational efforts, investing in their development as leading scholar-teachers in their fields. Building on the success of past Division of Molecular and Cellular Biosciences CAREER Awardee Conferences since 2019, the 2023 meeting will bring together a diverse cohort of awardees to foster cross-disciplinary interactions and build a community to advance molecular and cellular scale understanding of complex biological systems.

The goals of the conference are to facilitate knowledge sharing and catalyze collaborations among early-career faculty who span a broad range of research and educational expertise, and to provide input to the NSF on new research frontiers in molecular and cellular biosciences.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.
org_div_long_name: Division of Molecular and Cellular Biosciences

por.por_cntn:
The fourth annual NSF/MCB CAREER Awardee Conference, held November 13-14 2023 in Alexandria, VA, brought together a diverse group of awardees and trainees from the Molecular and Cellular Biosciences Division of the NSF. The conference was a forum for participants to broaden the scope of their research and teaching through exposure to new technologies, pedagogical approaches, and research questions. The conference spanned 1.5 days and included research talks, poster and brainstorming/discussion sessions, interactions with program directors from multiple NSF directorates, and peer networking opportunities. The conference goals were to foster interactions and potential collaborations among early-career faculty from diverse research areas, and to provide feedback to the NSF on new research frontiers.

Intellectual merit

The conference promoted the sharing of ideas and peer mentoring to support the CAREER awardees as scholars and educators. Postdoctoral researchers in CAREER awardee labs were also among the participants who benefited from networking opportunities and learning about NSF funding opportunities. The meeting built on the success of previous conferences with some changes based on feedback from previous participants from previous years. The program organization was designed to meet the conference objectives through creating opportunities for networking and both structured and informal discussions of science, education, and greater scientific challenges relevant to the NSF/MCB community. Through discussions, participants identified overlapping interests, potential areas for synergies, and identified solutions to shared challenges. The conference fostered new ideas and potential seeds for collaborations to explore complex biological systems at the cellular and molecular level through integrated approaches in systems and computational biology, genetics, cell/molecular biology, and biophysics.

Broader Impacts

The conference fostered the exchange of ideas among early career faculty who have been identified as potential leaders in research and teaching. The conference aligns with the CAREER program goals to create synergies between scientific discovery and learning. Through sharing best practices and learning from the experiences of their peers, participants strengthened the foundations of their teaching and research programs.

Outcomes

A survey of participants following the conference indicated that many of the meeting goals were met. Participants reported that this was a unique conference in its diversity of research topics. Participants also reported that they valued the networking opportunities, including the chance to meet other CAREER awardees and NSF program directors. They also reported the value in being exposed to new techniques, research ideas, and potential collaborators. The conference materials and survey were shared with the organizers of future conferences to benefit future participants.

 


Last Modified: 09/27/2024
Modified by: Amanda M Larracuente
